name: Alfalfa meal, dehydrated, protein < 16%
warning: High fiber limits monogastric inclusion; saponins may affect palatability
regulatory_note: EU: max 10% in poultry; organic certified sources preferred
notes: Rich in carotenes, good for pigmentation

name: Apple pomace, dried
warning: Low energy density; may contain pesticide residues
regulatory_note: EU: max 10% feed materials of fruit origin; pesticide screening required
notes: Pectin content may cause wet droppings

name: Bakery byproduct
warning: Variable salt content; may contain chocolate/toxic additives
regulatory_note: US FDA: Requires mycotoxin screening; EU: max 5% chocolate/cocoa contamination
notes: Check for raisin/chocolate content; sodium may vary 0.5-2%

name: Banana meal, immature, dried
warning: High tannin content in unripe bananas; variable trypsin inhibitor activity
regulatory_note: ASEAN: Max 30% fruit by-products in compound feeds
notes: Good energy source but low protein; use with amino acid supplementation

name: Barley
warning: Beta-glucans may cause viscosity issues; contains some anti-nutritional factors
regulatory_note: Codex: Standard for barley grain; EU: Ungmo status allowed
notes: Consider enzyme supplementation for monogastrics; good for ruminants

name: Barley distillers grains, dried
warning: High unsaturated fat may cause soft pork; mycotoxin risk from barley
regulatory_note: EU: Mycotoxin testing mandatory; max 40% in pig diets per CVB
notes: Good protein source; monitor fat quality for pig carcasses

name: Beet pulp, dried
warning: High pectin may cause diarrhea in pigs; low phosphorus availability
regulatory_note: EU: Approved for all species; molassed form higher energy
notes: Good energy for ruminants; excellent pelleting aid

name: Biscuit byproduct
warning: High sugar and fat may cause rancidity; check for hydrogenated fats
regulatory_note: US: GRAS status; EU: Category 3 material must be heat treated per 1774/2002
notes: Very palatable; variable composition

name: Black soldier fly larvae meal, fat < 20%
standardized_name: Black soldier fly larvae meal, fat < 20%
warning: High calcium may unbalance Ca:P ratio; heavy metal monitoring required
regulatory_note: EU Reg 2017/893: Approved species and limits strictly enforced; substrate must be feed-grade
notes: Sustainable protein; chitin may limit digestibility at high inclusion

name: Black soldier fly larvae meal, fat > 20%
standardized_name: Black soldier fly larvae meal, fat > 20%
warning: Very high fat leads to soft carcass; rancidity risk; Ca:P imbalance
regulatory_note: Same as ID9; substrate documentation mandatory
notes: Energy-rich variant; use antioxidant protection

name: Blood meal
warning: Extremely low isoleucine; high leucine can cause antagonism; poor palatability
regulatory_note: EU: Category 3 material; heat treatment 133°C/20min per 1774/2002; BSE/TSE free
notes: Use with isoleucine supplementation; excellent lysine source

name: Bone meal
warning: RUMINANTS ONLY in EU; BSE risk; high Ca:P ratio unbalanced
regulatory_note: US: Banned from ruminant feed (21 CFR 589.2000); EU: PAP ban; check local regs
notes: Use dicalcium phosphate for monogastrics; steam sterilization required

name: Brewers grains, dried
warning: High fiber reduces energy; tannins present; mycotoxin risk
regulatory_note: EU: Mycotoxin screening required; max 40% in dairy cows per CVB
notes: Excellent rumen bypass protein; good for dairy cows

name: Brewers yeast, dried
warning: High nucleic acids may increase uric acid; rich in B-vitamins
regulatory_note: EU: Category 3 material; GRAS status in US
notes: Excellent palatability enhancer; good source of B-vitamins and minerals

name: Calcium carbonate (limestone)
warning: Particle size critical for layers (>3mm for slow release)
regulatory_note: Feed-grade limestone per AAFCO; heavy metal limits EU 1881/2006
notes: Use coarse grind for layers, fine for pigs; 38% Ca

name: Canola meal, solvent extracted, oil < 5%
warning: Limit to 20% for pigs due to glucosinolates and fiber content. Higher levels may reduce palatability and performance.
regulatory_note: EU: Double-zero varieties mandatory; glucosinolates max 10 μmol/g meal
notes: Good amino acid profile; heat treatment improves digestibility

name: Cassava pulp, dried
warning: Very low protein and high fiber; HCN risk if not properly processed
regulatory_note: FAO: HCN must be <50 ppm; detoxification mandatory
notes: By-product of starch extraction; good energy but requires protein supplementation

name: Cassava root meal, dried
warning: Contains cyanogenic glycosides. Ensure proper processing (sun-drying/fermentation) to reduce toxicity. Limit to 40% for pigs.
regulatory_note: FAO/WHO: HCN limit 50 ppm; FDA GRAS for food use; feed limit 30%
notes: Excellent energy source; detoxification critical; use with methionine supplement

name: Cassava leaves, dried
warning: High HCN potential in fresh leaves; must be dried >80°C; tannins present
regulatory_note: FAO: Must be properly dried to reduce HCN; not approved in EU as feed
notes: Protein-rich but requires detoxification; excellent for ruminants when processed

name: Chickpea, kabuli type
warning: Trypsin inhibitors present; heat treatment required; oligosaccharides cause gas
regulatory_note: EU: Must be heat treated; ASAE: Trypsin inhibitor <4 mg/g
notes: Good protein source; requires heating; supplement methionine

name: Citrus pulp, dried
warning: High pectin causes diarrhea; limonene may affect palatability; low digestibility
regulatory_note: EU: Max 5% in poultry; pesticide residues monitored per 396/2005
notes: Good for ruminants; pellet binding agent; reduces urine pH in pigs

name: Cocoa hulls
warning: THEOBROMINE toxicity risk! Max 0.08% theobromine in feed; NOT for monogastrics
regulatory_note: EU: Cocoa shells prohibited in non-ruminant feeds; max 5% in cattle feed
notes: Ruminant feed only; theobromine limits usage

name: Cocoa meal, oil < 5%
warning: THEOBROMINE 0.5-1.0%; NOT for monogastrics; limit to 5% in ruminants
regulatory_note: EU: Category 3 material; max 5% in ruminant feeds; prohibited in non-ruminants
notes: Limited use due to theobromine; better as fertilizer than feed

name: Cod liver oil
warning: Very high vitamins A & D - hypervitaminosis risk; oxidation prone
regulatory_note: EU: Vitamin A max 12500 IU/kg feed; monitor levels; fish source certified
notes: Rich in EPA/DHA and vitamins; use with antioxidant protection

name: Common bean (Phaseolus vulgaris)
warning: LECTINS toxic if raw! Must be heat treated >95°C; trypsin inhibitors
regulatory_note: EU: Must be heat treated per 68/2013; FDA: Raw beans prohibited in feeds
notes: Excellent protein after cooking; lectins destroyed by heat; supplement methionine

name: Cottonseed hulls
warning: Extremely high fiber; low digestibility; may contain pesticide residues
regulatory_note: US: Noxious weed seed limit; EU: Max 15% in ruminant diets
notes: Used as bulk fiber; very low nutritional value; good for rumen fill

name: Cottonseed meal, oil 5-20%, fiber 15-20%
warning: GOSSYPOL toxicity! Free gossypol max 20 ppm for pigs, 0 ppm for layers
regulatory_note: US FDA: Max 100 ppm free gossypol; EU: Total gossypol <1.2% in feed; layers prohibited
notes: Must use gossypol-free varieties for layers; iron sulfate can bind gossypol

name: Cottonseed, whole
warning: VERY HIGH free gossypol (3500 ppm); toxic to non-ruminants; limit to 5% in pigs
regulatory_note: Same as cottonseed meal; whole seed higher gossypol risk
notes: Pressing/extrusion reduces gossypol; better for ruminants; iron binding needed

name: Cowpea (Black-eyed pea)
warning: Trypsin inhibitors require heat treatment; tannins moderate
regulatory_note: Same as other legumes; heat treatment mandatory per EU 68/2013
notes: Better than common beans; good drought tolerance; supplement methionine

name: Dicalcium phosphate (dihydrate)
warning: Keep Ca:P ratio 1.5-2:1 in diet; excessive Ca reduces other mineral absorption
regulatory_note: EU: Heavy metal limits Cd <10 mg/kg, Pb <30 mg/kg per 1881/2006
notes: Standard phosphorus source; 18% P, 23% Ca; use with limestone for layers

name: DL-Methionine (99%)
warning: Acidic; handle with care; dust hazard; non-ruminant use only
regulatory_note: AAFCO approved; EU 1831/2003 as feed additive; FAMI-QS certified
notes: First limiting amino acid in corn-soy diets; 99% pure methionine

name: Dolomite limestone
warning: Magnesium may cause diarrhea; not primary Ca source for high-producing layers
regulatory_note: US: Limestone must be >33% Ca; EU: Magnesium limit 0.5% in complete feed
notes: Provides both Ca and Mg; 21.9% Ca, 11.5% Mg; use with caution

name: Enzyme (phytase, typical)
warning: Store cool and dry; activity loss >25°C; avoid direct mixing with minerals
regulatory_note: EU 1831/2003 as feed additive; FDA GRAS; must declare activity units
notes: Releases phytate phosphorus (500-1000 FTU/g); reduces P excretion; Releases phytate phosphorus, typically 500-1000 FTU/g

name: Faba bean, colored flowers
warning: VICINE/CONVICINE causes egg taint; tannins; favism in sensitive breeds
regulatory_note: EU: Max 10% in layer diets; vicine/convicine <0.05% in feed
notes: Colored varieties higher in ANFs; white flowered (ID35) safer; heat treat

name: Faba bean, white flowers
warning: Lower vicine/convicine but still present; tannins mild
regulatory_note: Preferred faba bean variety; same EU limits as ID34
notes: Safer for layers than colored varieties; good protein source; heat treat

name: Feather meal
warning: Poor lysine digestibility; high cystine; hydrolysis quality critical
regulatory_note: US: Must be hydrolyzed; EU: Heat treatment 133°C/20min; Category 3
notes: Excellent cystine source; poor lysine; modern processing improves digestibility; High in cystine, poor lysine digestibility

name: Fish meal, 62% protein
warning: Avoid rancidity; dioxin/PCB monitoring; SRM ban compliance
regulatory_note: EU: Heavy metal limits; dioxin max 0.75 ng/kg; SRM ban per 999/2001
notes: Premium protein; excellent AA profile; use antioxidant protection

name: Fish meal, 65% protein
warning: Same as ID37; higher protein grade; oxidation stability critical
regulatory_note: Same regulatory compliance as ID37; premium grade
notes: Higher protein content; better amino acid balance; excellent for fish

name: Fish meal, 70% protein
warning: Premium grade fish meal; same dioxin/PCB risks; quality control essential
regulatory_note: Same as ID37; highest protein grade; more expensive but less ash
notes: Lowest ash content; best digestibility; ideal for high-value fish and shrimp

name: Fish oil
warning: Rancidity risk; fishy taint in eggs >2%; oxidation products toxic
regulatory_note: EU: Dioxin max 0.75 ng/kg; oxidation stability required; EPA/DHA source
notes: Rich in omega-3 (EPA/DHA); use antioxidant protection; premium energy source; Rich in omega-3 fatty acids (EPA, DHA)

name: Fish oil
warning: High PUFA content - prone to oxidation. Requires antioxidant protection (≥200mg/kg BHT/ETQ). Risk of dioxin/PCB contamination - source from certified suppliers. Unsuitable for ruminants >5% due to milk fat depression. Store under nitrogen blanket.
regulatory_note: FDA 21 CFR 579.40 - must be from BSE-free sources. EU maximum dioxin limit: 2pg WHO-TEQ/g fat. Must declare EPA/DHA content. Kosher/Halal certification required for some markets. Chain of custody documentation mandatory.
notes: Rich in omega-3 fatty acids (EPA, DHA). Excellent for aquaculture (salmonids). Improves feed conversion and immune function. High cost limits use. Requires antioxidant stabilization.

name: Fodder beet, raw
warning: High moisture content (85%) limits storage and transport. Can cause diarrhea if introduced rapidly. Low dry matter reduces nutritional density. Not suitable for mechanical feeding systems. Risk of soil contamination during harvest.
regulatory_note: No specific regulations. Must meet general feed hygiene standards (EC 183/2005). Soil contamination <3% DM. Free from chemical residues. Not classified as feed additive.
notes: High moisture root crop mainly for ruminants. Energy primarily from sugars. Requires washing to remove soil. Gradual introduction essential. Best used fresh or ensiled.

name: Grape pomace, dried
warning: Very high tannin content (3.5%) causes protein binding and reduced palatability. Can cause dark yolks in layers. Low digestibility due to lignin. Risk of pesticide residues from vineyard treatments. Mycotoxin risk if moldy grapes used.
regulatory_note: EU Feed Materials Register: 1.2.8-06. Tannin content must be declared. Maximum recommended inclusion: 5% in piglet diets, 10% in poultry. Must comply with pesticide residue limits (EC 396/2005). Not permitted in aquaculture.
notes: Byproduct of wine production. High fiber and tannins limit use. Contains polyphenols with antioxidant properties. Best used in ruminant diets. Gradual introduction required. Monitor for ochratoxin A from grapes.

name: Grape seeds
warning: Extremely high tannin content (4.5%) and fiber (39%) severely limit digestibility. Very hard texture reduces palatability. Can cause gizzard erosion in poultry. Oil extraction recommended before use. Risk of aflatoxin from contaminated grapes.
regulatory_note: EU Feed Materials Register: 1.2.8-07. Classified as roughage. Tannin content >4% must be declared. Not recommended for monogastric starter diets. Veterinary approval required in some jurisdictions for inclusion >10%.
notes: Very high fiber content limits use. Oil can be extracted for higher value. Best used as roughage for ruminants. Requires grinding for monogastrics. Contains proanthocyanidins with antioxidant properties but high tannin binding capacity.

name: Milk powder, whole
warning: Very high fat (26%) causes rancidity; lactose; extreme cost; use antioxidant
regulatory_note: US: Grade A standards; microbiological limits; EU Category 3
notes: High-energy milk replacer; use for young animals only; excellent palatability

name: Millet, pearl
warning: Tannins 0.5% limit use; smaller grain size; dust hazard
regulatory_note: FAO: Minor cereal; EU: Approved; phytate P high
notes: Drought-tolerant alternative to maize; lower energy; good for semi-arid regions

name: Molasses, beet
warning: High sugar (>40%) causes diarrhea in pigs; Ruminal acidosis >10% in cattle
regulatory_note: EU: Max 10% in ruminants to avoid acidosis; US: GRAS status
notes: Excellent palatability; reduces dust; good energy; limit for gut health; Liquid, improves palatability

name: Molasses, sugarcane
warning: Lower protein than beet molasses; higher ash; acidosis risk in ruminants >15%
regulatory_note: Same as beet molasses; more variable composition; higher potassium
notes: More common than beet molasses; cheaper but lower quality; palatability enhancer

name: Monocalcium phosphate
warning: Very high phosphorus; maintain Ca:P ratio 1.5-2:1; excessive P is environmental issue
regulatory_note: EU: Heavy metal limits; environmental regulations on P excretion
notes: 22.4% P, 16.7% Ca; highly available; standard P source

name: Moringa leaves, dried
warning: High calcium may unbalance ratio; alkaloids present; heavy metal uptake from soil
regulatory_note: EU: Not listed in EU feed materials; check local regulations; heavy metal monitoring
notes: Superfood potential but regulatory issues; excellent vitamins A, C; source verification critical; Very rich in vitamins A, C, calcium; limit 5-10%

name: Neem cake (detoxified)
warning: BITTER compounds limit intake; azadirachtin toxicity if not properly detoxified
regulatory_note: EU: Not approved as feed; India: FSSAI regulates; check local approval
notes: Controversial; detoxification critical; limited research; use with extreme caution; Limit to 5% due to bitter compounds

name: Noodle waste
warning: High salt content; variable composition; may contain spices/onion/garlic
regulatory_note: US: GRAS; EU: Food waste must be heat treated per 1069/2009
notes: Good energy from starch; palatable; check for toxic additives; quality control essential

name: Oat hulls
warning: Very high fiber; extremely low density; dusty; poor digestibility
regulatory_note: EU: Max 15% in pig feed; natural fiber source; no contaminants
notes: Used as fiber source; very low energy; good for gut motility; dust control needed

name: Oats
warning: Beta-glucans cause viscosity; need enzyme supplementation; lower energy than corn
regulatory_note: EU: Beta-glucanase recommended; CVB provides enzyme correction factors
notes: Good for sow lactation; beta-glucans benefit gut health with enzyme; less mycotoxin than corn

name: Palm kernel meal, oil 5-20%
warning: Very high fiber (19%) severely limits monogastric use.Contains beta-mannan lectins that can be anti-nutritional. Poor amino acid profile - very deficient in lysine, methionine and threonine.
regulatory_note: ASEAN: Common ingredient; EU: Max 10% in monogastric feeds
notes: Low digestibility; better for ruminants; limit for monogastrics; cheap fiber source; Oil palm fruit by-product. Very high fiber severely limits use in poultry and pigs. Better suited for ruminants (good bypass protein). Energy from remaining oil. Lysine is extremely deficient. High fiber good for ruminant rumen function but limits intake.

name: Palm oil
warning: High palmitic acid; hard fat formation; rancidity risk; sustainable sourcing concerns
regulatory_note: EU: RSPO certification encouraged; heavy metal limits; no trans fats
notes: Saturated fat causes hard carcass fat; good for hot climates; sustainable sourcing important

name: Pea (field pea)
warning: Trypsin inhibitors require heat treatment; tannins; oligosaccharides cause gas
regulatory_note: EU: Must be heat treated 68/2013; trypsin inhibitor <2.5 mg/g
notes: Good alternative to soybean meal; heat treatment critical; supplement methionine

name: Pea, extruded
warning: Same ANFs as raw peas but reduced by extrusion; over-processing reduces lysine
regulatory_note: EU: Extrusion counts as heat treatment; digestibility improved 5-8%
notes: Improved digestibility over raw peas; better amino acid availability; good for piglets; Better digestibility than raw peas

name: Pigeon pea
warning: Protease inhibitors present; less research than other legumes; tannins
regulatory_note: Tropical legume; heat treatment required; less regulated data
notes: Drought-tolerant; moderate protein; heat treatment critical; good for tropics

name: Potato pulp, dried
warning: High fiber (16%); glycoalkaloids if green potatoes used; solanine risk
regulatory_note: EU: Must be from food-grade potatoes; solanine <2.5 mg/kg feed
notes: By-product of starch industry; pectin content; good for gut health; solanine monitoring needed

name: Potato tuber, dried
warning: Solanine risk if from green potatoes; high starch; low protein
regulatory_note: Same as potato pulp; must be from food-grade sources; solanine monitoring
notes: Good energy source; better protein than cereal grains; must verify solanine levels

name: Poultry fat
warning: Same-species feeding concerns (PAP ban); rancidity risk; quality variable
regulatory_note: CRITICAL: EU 999/2001 prohibits feeding poultry fat to poultry (same species), PAP ban - cannot feed to poultry! Ok for pigs, ruminants, fish
notes: Good energy; palatable; but legally cannot feed back to poultry in EU; US varies by state

name: Poultry by-product meal, 60-70% protein
warning: CANNOT FEED TO POULTRY (same species per EU PAP ban); high fat; rancidity
regulatory_note: EU 999/2001: STRICTLY PROHIBITED to feed PAP to same species (poultry to poultry), OK for pigs, ruminants, fish; but ILLEGAL to feed to poultry in EU; check local regs
notes: Excellent protein but species ban limits use; use for pigs/fish; high digestibility

name: Rapeseed meal, oil < 5%
warning: Higher glucosinolates than canola; erucic acid <5%; goitrogenic; limit to 10% layers
regulatory_note: EU: Max 12 μmol/g glucosinolates; double-zero varieties mandatory
notes: Lower energy than soybean; good methionine; glucosinolates limit poultry use

name: Rapeseed oil
warning: High unsaturated fat; soft carcass fat in pigs; oxidation risk; omega-3 content
regulatory_note: EU: Erucic acid limit <2% in oil; heavy metal limits; oxidation stability required
notes: Good energy source; better for poultry than pigs; monitor erucic acid; sustainable sourcing

name: Rice bran, defatted
warning: Extremely high phytate P (14%); rancidity risk even defatted; aflatoxin risk
regulatory_note: US: Max 50% rice bran in feed; EU: Aflatoxin monitoring critical; high phytate
notes: High phytate reduces mineral availability; use phytase; dust explosion risk; rancidity potential

name: Rice, brown
warning: Phytate high; lower energy than corn; arsenic uptake from flooded soils
regulatory_note: US: FDA monitors arsenic in rice; EU: Max 0.2 mg/kg arsenic in feed
notes: Good energy; phytate reduces mineral availability; arsenic concern; use phytase

name: Rice, polished (broken)
warning: Very low fiber; high starch; low protein; arsenic uptake variable
regulatory_note: Same arsenic concerns as brown rice; polishing removes bran but not arsenic
notes: Higher energy than brown rice; less fiber; better for pigs; arsenic still a concern

name: Rye
warning: Pentosans cause viscosity; ergot risk in contaminated batches; lower energy than corn
regulatory_note: EU: Ergot limit <0.5% in grain; pentosanase enzyme recommended; CVB values
notes: Better for ruminants than monogastrics; enzyme supplementation critical for poultry; ergot testing needed

name: Salt (Sodium chloride)
warning: TOXICITY risk >5%; sodium ion poisoning; provide adequate water; NOT for fish
regulatory_note: NRC: Max 0.4% Na in pig diets; EU: Max 0.5% in complete feed; FDA GRAS
notes: Essential electrolyte; 39.3% Na, 60.7% Cl; iodized salt recommended; uniform mixing critical

name: Seashells, ground
warning: Heavy metal contamination risk (ocean pollution); particle size affects solubility
regulatory_note: EU: Heavy metal limits (Pb, Cd, Hg) per 1881/2006; source verification needed
notes: 38% Ca; cheaper than limestone; marine source concerns; use coarse for layers; test purity

name: Sesame meal, oil > 5%
warning: Very high calcium (1.9%) unbalances Ca:P; phytates; oxalates limit calcium absorption
regulatory_note: AAFCO approved; EU: Max 10% in layer diets due to Ca imbalance
notes: Excellent methionine source; high Ca limits use; supplement phosphorus; good for layers (Ca benefit)

name: Shrimp meal
warning: HIGH CHITIN limits digestibility; very high calcium (11%) unbalances ratio; heavy metals from ocean
regulatory_note: EU: Heavy metal limits; chitin not digestible by monogastrics; marine source concerns
notes: Chitin limits use for monogastrics; excellent for fish; high calcium problematic; marine sustainability; High chitin content limits digestibility

name: Sodium bicarbonate
warning: Alkaline; can increase urine pH; acid-base balance; sodium load
regulatory_note: FDA GRAS; EU: Feed additive for rumen buffering; max 2% in dairy
notes: Buffer for heat stress; rumen alkalizer; urine alkalinizer; 27.4% Na; use for DCAD management; Buffer, electrolyte balance

name: Sorghum
warning: Tannins (0.5% limit use); mold risk; variable amino acid digestibility
regulatory_note: US: Low-tannin varieties preferred; high-tannin sorghum limit 20-30%; EU: Bird resistant varieties restricted
notes: Drought-tolerant corn alternative; low-tannin varieties good for all species; tannins reduce protein digestibility

name: Soybean hulls
warning: Extremely high fiber (35%); very low energy for poultry; heat damage risk
regulatory_note: US: Byproduct of soybean processing; EU: Category 3 material; mycotoxin risk from soy
notes: Excellent ruminant fiber; very low value for poultry; extremely low density; dust explosion risk

name: Soybean meal, 48% CP, extruded
warning: Same ANFs as SBM but trypsin inhibitors reduced; over-heating reduces lysine digestibility
regulatory_note: EU: Extrusion counts as sufficient heat treatment; better digestibility than solvent-extracted
notes: Gold standard protein; excellent amino acid profile; heat processing essential; phytase improves P availability; Improved digestibility over solvent-extracted; better protein quality; higher cost but worth it; Better digestibility than non-extruded

name: Soybean oil
warning: Polyunsaturated fats cause soft fat; oxidation risk; GMO concerns; allergenic
regulatory_note: EU: GMO labeling if >0.9%; oxidation stability required; sustainable sourcing encouraged
notes: Polyunsaturation problematic for pig carcass; good for poultry; sustainable sourcing issues; use antioxidant

name: Soybean, whole, extruded
warning: High fat (19%) plus protein can cause rancidity; trypsin inhibitors reduced but present
regulatory_note: EU: Extrusion sufficient heat treatment; better than raw soybeans; GMO labeling applies
notes: Full-fat soy; high energy; good for young pigs; rancidity concern; excellent bypass protein for ruminants

name: Sunflower hulls
warning: Extremely HIGH fiber (50%); lowest density; abrasive; very low nutritional value
regulatory_note: EU: Max 10% in monogastric feeds; natural fiber source; no restriction
notes: Used as filler/bulk; very low energy; dusty; good for rumen fill; quality control for purity

name: Sunflower meal, dehulled
warning: Deficient lysine (1.35%); high fiber (18%) limits use; phytates; good methionine
regulatory_note: AAFCO defines as >34% CP; EU: Max 20% in pig diets due to fiber
notes: Excellent methionine supplement; very low lysine causes imbalance; fiber limits monogastric use

name: Sunflower oil
warning: Polyunsaturated fat >70% causes soft fat; oxidation risk; vitamin E deficiency potential
regulatory_note: EU: High oleic varieties available; oxidation stability per 183/2005; heavy metal limits
notes: High linoleic acid; good for egg omega-3 enrichment; soft carcass fat in pigs; use with vitamin E

name: Sweet potato, dried
warning: Beta-carotene (vitamin A) can cause yellow fat; low protein; fiber okay
regulatory_note: US: GRAS; EU: Max 30% in pig diets; no major restrictions; pesticide screening
notes: Excellent energy; beta-carotene benefits layer yolk color; low protein requires supplementation

name: Tallow
regulatory_note: Check local regulations regarding animal fat usage in feed. Some regions have restrictions due to BSE concerns.
notes: Animal fat source. High energy. Use with antioxidant protection. Excellent for aquaculture.

name: Teff grain
notes: Gluten-free ancient grain. Good amino acid profile. Can replace maize/wheat up to 100%. High calcium content.

name: Tomato pulp, dehydrated
warning: High fiber content may reduce nutrient digestibility in young animals. Contains lycopene which may have antioxidant benefits.
notes: By-product of tomato processing. High fiber limits inclusion. Rich in lycopene. Good for ruminants and rabbits.

name: Toxin binder (clay-based)
warning: Do not exceed 5 kg/ton (0.5%). Overuse may bind essential nutrients and reduce feed efficiency.
regulatory_note: Approved as mycotoxin binder in most jurisdictions. Registration may be required.
notes: Clay-based toxin binder. Use at 1-2 kg/ton for mycotoxin control. Monitor for potential nutrient binding.; Binds mycotoxins, use 1-2 kg/ton

name: Vitamin-Mineral Premix (Layer)
warning: CONCENTRATE - NOT FOR DIRECT FEEDING. Overdosing can cause severe toxicity or death. Use only as directed.
regulatory_note: Regulated feed additive. Follow manufacturer specifications exactly. Contains high levels of vitamins and minerals.
notes: Layer premix concentrate. Use at 2.5-5 kg/ton of complete feed. Provides complete vitamin, mineral and amino acid supplementation. DO NOT FEED DIRECTLY.

name: Wheat, soft
notes: Standard soft wheat. Good energy source. Relatively low lysine. Can be major cereal component (up to 70%) in most species. Contains gluten.

name: Wheat bran
warning: High phosphorus content but mostly unavailable (phytate). Can contribute to environmental phosphorus pollution.
notes: High fiber by-product. Good laxative effect. High phytate phosphorus. Moderate energy. Excellent for ruminants and rabbits. Limit in young poultry due to fiber content.

name: Wheat gluten
warning: Low lysine relative to protein content. Expensive - use based on economics.
notes: Very high protein concentrate (80%). Excellent amino acid profile except lysine. Used as specialty protein source. Bypass protein for ruminants. Excellent for aquaculture.

name: Wheat middlings
warning: High phytate phosphorus reduces mineral availability. May contain weed seeds.
notes: Wheat milling by-product. Moderate fiber and protein. Good energy value. Cost-effective ingredient. Phosphorus availability is low.

name: Wheat straw
warning: Very low nutritional value. High silica content can cause digestive irritation. Not suitable for monogastrics.
notes: Very high fiber, low energy roughage. Primarily for ruminant bulk feed or bedding. Contains high silica. Poor digestibility for non-ruminants.

name: Whey powder, acid
warning: High lactose content can cause diarrhea in older pigs and poultry. Acid whey has lower pH - may affect feed stability.
regulatory_note: Dairy product - generally recognized as safe. Quality control essential.
notes: Good protein quality (high lysine). High in lactose. Limit in older animals due to lactose intolerance. Excellent for young pigs. Acid whey has lower pH and different mineral profile than sweet whey.

name: Whey powder, sweet
warning: High lactose content can cause digestive upset. Sweet whey is more palatable than acid whey but still limits inclusion in poultry.
regulatory_note: Dairy product - generally recognized as safe.
notes: Higher energy than acid whey. Better palatability. High quality protein. Lactose can cause diarrhea in monogastrics if included too high. Excellent for young piglets.

name: Yeast, Single Cell Protein
warning: High nucleic acid content may increase uric acid levels at high inclusion rates. Rich in B-vitamins.
regulatory_note: Approved for feed use. Source may be from sugarcane ethanol production (yeast).
notes: Single cell protein from yeast fermentation. High quality protein. Bypass protein for ruminants. Excellent for aquaculture. Contains high levels of B-vitamins. Nucleic acids may limit inclusion in some species.

name: Azolla (Aquatic fern)
warning: High ash content (18%) may limit inclusion. Must be properly dried to prevent mold growth. Fresh form has 90-95% moisture.
notes: Aquatic fern with moderate protein. High ash content limits use. Must be dried before use. Can be cultivated on-farm. Good protein source for ruminants and fish.; Use dried form; high moisture when fresh

name: Lemna (Duckweed)
warning: High ash content reduces energy density. Must be dried properly. Can accumulate heavy metals if grown in contaminated water.
notes: Protein-rich aquatic plant (35% CP). Better amino acid profile than many plant proteins. Excellent for aquaculture (tilapia, carp). Can be cultivated on-farm. High growth rate. Fiber and ash limit inclusion.; Protein-rich aquatic plant

name: Wolffia (Watermeal)
warning: Highest protein aquatic plant available. High ash content still limits inclusion. Ensure clean water source to avoid heavy metal contamination.
notes: Exceptional protein content (40%) for a plant source. Excellent amino acid profile. World's smallest flowering plant. Rapid growth. Outstanding for aquaculture and as protein supplement for all species. Still limited by ash content.; Highest protein aquatic plant

name: Bambara groundnut
warning: Contains anti-nutritional factors (trypsin inhibitors, tannins). Must be heat treated before use in monogastrics. Raw form not recommended.
notes: African legume. Good protein and energy. Contains anti-nutritional factors that require processing (roasting, extrusion). Similar to peanuts. Good drought tolerance. Must be processed for poultry and pigs.

name: Baobab fruit pulp
warning: Contains tannins and oxalates which may reduce protein digestibility. High vitamin C may affect feed stability.
regulatory_note: Generally recognized as safe. Novel ingredient in many regions.
notes: Baobab fruit pulp. Low protein but high in vitamin C (5000 mg/kg), calcium and fiber. Pleasant taste improves palatability. Antioxidant properties. Limited by anti-nutritional factors.; High in vitamin C and fiber

name: Baobab leaf powder
warning: Very high calcium (28 g/kg) can disrupt Ca:P ratio. High tannin and oxalate content reduce nutrient availability. Extremely high fiber limits digestibility.
notes: Leaf powder very high in calcium and fiber. Rich in vitamins A and C. Anti-nutritional factors limit inclusion. Better for ruminants than monogastrics. High price limits commercial use.; Rich in vitamins A, C; limit to 5%

name: Bamboo leaves, dried
warning: Exceptionally high fiber (35%) severely limits digestibility. Very high calcium can disrupt mineral balance. High silica content may irritate digestive tract.
notes: Very high fiber leaf meal. Low energy density. High silica and calcium. Primarily for ruminant roughage or rabbit fiber. Not suitable for high-performance animals. Limited commercial feed use.; Very high fiber, limit to 5%

name: Corn Silage (Maize Silage)
warning: RUMINANTS ONLY. High moisture (65%) makes it unsuitable for monogastrics. Potential for botulism if not properly fermented. Contains organic acids that may be unpalatable in high amounts.
regulatory_note: Silage quality critical - must be properly fermented to prevent spoilage and toxin formation.
notes: Fermented forage for ruminants. High moisture content requires proper storage. Good energy from starch and fiber. Lactic acid fermentation provides preservative effect. Use as-fed basis. Not for pigs or poultry.; High moisture (65%), fermented feed for ruminants

name: Corn Flour (Maize Flour)
warning: Low protein and lysine content. High mycotoxin risk - requires stringent quality control. Fine particle size may cause digestive issues if not pelleted.
notes: Fine ground maize. Excellent energy source. Low fiber. Very low protein and lysine - must supplement amino acids. Mycotoxin contamination is major concern. Can replace maize grain up to 100% with proper supplementation.

name: Coconut Meal (Copra meal)
warning: Severe lysine deficiency (limiting amino acid). High fiber and fat content. Risk of aflatoxin contamination if not properly dried. High arginine may antagonize lysine.
notes: Coconut processing by-product. Very deficient in lysine - requires supplementation. High fiber limits monogastric use. Good bypass protein for ruminants. High oil content (>8%) provides energy but can cause soft fat in pigs/poultry. Must be aflatoxin tested.

name: Black Gram (Urad dal)
warning: Contains anti-nutritional factors (trypsin inhibitors, tannins). Must be heat treated (cooked, extruded) before use in monogastrics. Raw form not recommended for poultry or young pigs.
notes: Legume seed popular in South Asia. Good protein content but deficient in methionine. Contains heat-labile anti-nutritional factors. Requires processing for optimal digestibility. Can partially replace soybean meal when processed properly.

name: Pigeon Pea (Arhar dal)
warning: Contains trypsin inhibitors and tannins. Heat treatment recommended for monogastric use. Moderate lysine deficiency.
notes: Drought-tolerant legume. Good protein and starch. Deficient in methionine and lysine. Contains anti-nutritional factors. Processing (toasting, extrusion) improves digestibility. Can replace soybean meal partially (30-50%) when processed.

name: Finger Millet (Ragi)
warning: High calcium content may disrupt Ca:P ratio in high inclusion diets. Contains tannins that reduce protein digestibility. Phytic acid reduces mineral availability.
notes: Millet variety with exceptionally high calcium (3.4 g/kg). Good for layers but requires phosphorus supplementation. Moderate tannins limit inclusion. Good energy from starch. Gluten-free cereal. Can replace maize up to 50% with proper balancing.

name: Green Gram (Mung bean)
warning: Contains trypsin inhibitors. Heat treatment (cooking, extrusion) required for optimal digestibility. Raw form has lower amino acid availability.
notes: Highly digestible legume. Good protein quality. Low anti-nutritional factors compared to other legumes. Heat processing improves digestibility. Can replace soybean meal up to 50% in most species when heated. Good for aquaculture.

name: Sorghum grain, whole
warning: High tannin varieties severely limit use for monogastrics. Low-tannin varieties must be specified for poultry and pigs. Tannins reduce protein digestibility and palatability.
notes: Important cereal in dry regions. Can replace maize up to 100% with low-tannin varieties. High-tannin varieties limit to 20-30% for monogastrics. Good energy source for ruminants. Requires amino acid supplementation due to low lysine and threonine.

name: Millet, proso (whole)
notes: Proso millet with excellent methionine content (4.5 g/kg) - higher than most cereals. Good energy source. Gluten-free. Can replace maize up to 100% with amino acid supplementation. No major anti-nutritional factors. Good for all species.

name: Millet, foxtail (Setaria)
notes: Foxtail millet. Good energy cereal. Moderate protein. Low tannins. Gluten-free. Can replace maize up to 100% with amino acid supplementation. No major anti-nutritional factors. Good alternative grain for all species.

name: Rice hulls
warning: Very high silica (15%) - abrasive to equipment and digestive tract. Extremely low nutritional value. Negligible protein digestibility. High fiber. Primarily used as diluent or bedding.
notes: By-product of rice milling. Very high silica and fiber. Poorly digestible for all species. Used as fiber source in small amounts or as bedding material. Can reduce pellet quality. High inclusion will severely dilute diet energy and protein.

name: Rapeseed meal, oil 5-20%
warning: HIGH GLUCOSINOLATES (15 μmol/g). Can cause thyroid enlargement, liver damage, and reduced performance. Limit to achieve max 2-3 mmol glucosinolates per kg diet. Erucic acid may cause heart lesions.
regulatory_note: Maximum glucosinolate levels regulated in EU and many countries. Check local limits. Double-zero (00) varieties are required for higher inclusion rates.
notes: Rapeseed meal with oil (higher energy than extracted). High glucosinolates severely limit inclusion. Must be limited to avoid thyroid and liver issues. Good protein quality if anti-nutritional factors are low. Double-zero varieties allow 200-300 g/kg inclusion.

name: Sweet potato root, dried
warning: Very low protein (5.5%) - must supplement with protein sources. High moisture fresh form not suitable. Beta-carotene content may affect egg yolk color in layers.
notes: Excellent energy source from starch. Very low protein requires supplementation. Good for all species as energy replacement for cereals. High fiber limits use in young poultry. Beta-carotene provides vitamin A activity and may color egg yolks. Easily digestible when cooked.

name: Grape pulp, dried
warning: EXTREMELY HIGH TANNINS (3-4%). Severely reduces protein digestibility and palatability. High calcium may disrupt mineral balance. Polyphenols can bind nutrients.
notes: Wine industry by-product. High tannins severely limit use. Good fiber source for ruminants when limited to 10-15% of diet. Antioxidant properties from polyphenols. Very low digestibility for monogastrics. Cost-effective fiber source for ruminants only.

name: Locust bean pod meal (Parkia)
warning: Sweet taste improves palatability but very low protein requires heavy supplementation. Anti-nutritional factors limit inclusion.
notes: Also known as carob. Pods are sweet (sucrose content) improving palatability. Low protein and energy. Moderate fiber. Used as binder in pet foods. Good source of soluble fiber (pectin). Can partially replace cereals in ruminant diets. Cost effective for ruminants.

name: Sheanut oil meal (Shea cake)
warning: High fat content (10.8%) may soften carcass fat. Poor amino acid profile - very deficient in lysine and methionine. Residual fat can become rancid without antioxidant protection.
notes: Shea nut processing by-product. Moderate protein but poor quality. High fat provides energy but must be stabilized. High fiber limits monogastric use. Better for ruminants. Low cost but requires heavy amino acid supplementation. Not common in commercial feeds.

name: Okra seed meal (Abelmoschus)
warning: High fat content (15.5%) may cause soft carcass fat and rancidity. High fiber limits monogastric digestibility. Must be stabilized with antioxidant. Deficient in lysine and methionine.
notes: Okra seed meal. High oil content provides energy but requires stabilization. Good protein level but poor amino acid balance. Fiber limits monogastric inclusion. Moderate protein quality. Unconventional ingredient - limited data available.

name: Cassava peel, dried
warning: DANGER: High cyanogenic glycosides (150 ppm HCN potential). MUST be dried and processed properly. Maximum 50 ppm HCN in final feed. Can cause acute cyanide poisoning. High fiber and low digestibility.
regulatory_note: Maximum HCN levels regulated. Requires processing (sun drying, ensiling, or chemical treatment) to reduce HCN content below 50 ppm.
notes: DANGEROUS IF NOT PROCESSED PROPERLY. Cassava peel contains much higher cyanogenic glycosides than root. Requires extensive processing (sun drying 3-5 days, or cooking, or ensiling 30 days) to reduce HCN. Very low nutritional value. Use with extreme caution. Better for ruminants than monogastrics.

name: Mustard bran
warning: EXTREMELY HIGH GLUCOSINOLATES (25 μmol/g) - TOXIC. Can cause severe thyroid enlargement, goiter, liver damage, and death. Maximum 5-8% inclusion (50-80 g/kg). Strictly limit to avoid toxicity.
regulatory_note: HIGHLY REGULATED. Glucosinolate levels must be monitored. EU regulations limit glucosinolate intake to 2-3 mmol/kg diet. Mustard bran is one of highest glucosinolate sources.
notes: MUSTARD BRAN HAS HIGH TOXICITY RISK. Very high glucosinolates and erucic acid severely limit inclusion. Even at 5-8% inclusion requires careful formulation. Only for mature animals. Better for ruminants than monogastrics. High fiber and fat. Unsuitable for young animals or high-performance diets.

name: Winged bean pod, dried (Psophocarpus)
warning: Contains trypsin inhibitors. Must be heat treated (cooked, extruded) for optimal protein digestibility. High calcium may affect mineral balance in high inclusion diets.
notes: Winged bean pods (not seeds). Moderate protein with good amino acid profile. Trypsin inhibitors limit raw use. Lower energy than seeds due to fiber. Can partially replace soybean meal when processed. Novel ingredient - limited commercial data.

name: Wheat feed flour
warning: Contains gluten - avoid for gluten-free formulations. Moderate mycotoxin risk. Phytic acid reduces mineral availability.
notes: Fine wheat flour by-product. Low fiber, good energy. Can replace maize up to 80% in most species. Moderate protein but low lysine. Better digestibility than bran. Cost-effective energy source. Contains gluten.

name: Soybean molasses
warning: Liquid form - requires specialized handling equipment. Very high oligosaccharides can cause flatulence and digestive upset in monogastrics. High moisture (25%) reduces shelf life if not preserved.
notes: By-product of soybean processing. High in sugars (raffinose, stachyose) that cause gas and reduce digestibility. Sweet taste improves palatability. Low protein. Can replace molasses in ruminant diets. High phosphorus. Oligosaccharides limit monogastric inclusion.

name: Urea (Non-protein nitrogen, 46% N)
warning: DANGEROUS - Ruminants only. Can cause ammonia toxicity. Slow introduction required.
regulatory_note: REGULATED SUBSTANCE. Strict maximum inclusion rates apply. Requires slow adaptation period. Must be mixed thoroughly to avoid toxicity pockets. Not permitted in some organic systems.
notes: Non-protein nitrogen source for ruminants only. Provides nitrogen for rumen microbes to synthesize protein. 46% nitrogen × 6.25 = 287.5% crude protein equivalent. Requires adaptation period. Must have adequate fermentable energy (starch) in diet. Overfeeding causes rapid ammonia release and toxicity. Very cost-effective protein equivalent.; Nitrogen equivalent: 46% N Ã— 6.25 = 287.5% CP equivalent. RUMINANTS ONLY!

name: Monodicalcium phosphate
warning: CONCENTRATED MINERAL SOURCE - DO NOT OVERDOSE. Over-supplementation can cause urinary calculi, reduce mineral absorption, and cause skeletal issues. Ensure balanced Ca:P ratio in final diet.
regulatory_note: Feed-grade phosphate. Quality critical - heavy metal contaminants must be below regulatory limits.
notes: Balanced calcium (17.3%) and phosphorus (22.2%) mineral source. Phosphorus 100% available. Used to meet Ca and P requirements. Low inclusion rate (1-2%). High biological value. Monitor for heavy metal contamination. Better Ca:P ratio than dicalcium phosphate.

name: Processed animal protein, pig (porcine meal)
warning: SPECIES RESTRICTION: CANNOT be fed to pigs (same species) - risk of disease transmission. OK for poultry, ruminants, rabbits, fish. Subject to strict regulations. Ensure product is properly heat-treated for pathogen control.
regulatory_note: Subject to strict regulations - check local laws on processed animal proteins
notes: Rendered pig protein. Excellent amino acid profile. High Ca and P. Banned for pigs (cannibalism risk). Good for poultry, fish, ruminants. Regulatory restrictions apply. Ensure proper processing to kill pathogens. Cost-effective protein for non-pig species.

name: Processed animal protein, poultry, 45-60% protein
warning: SPECIES RESTRICTION: CANNOT be fed to poultry (same species). OK for pigs, ruminants, rabbits, fish. High fat content (28%) can cause rancidity - requires antioxidant. Risk of disease transmission if not properly processed.
regulatory_note: Subject to strict regulations - check local laws on processed animal proteins
notes: Rendered poultry protein (mid-fat grade). Excellent for pigs and aquaculture. BANNED for poultry (cannibalism risk). High energy from fat. Must be stabilized. Cost-effective alternative to fish meal for pigs/fish. High quality protein and amino acids.

name: Processed animal protein, poultry, 60-70% protein
warning: SPECIES RESTRICTION: CANNOT be fed to poultry (same species). OK for pigs, ruminants, rabbits, fish. Higher protein grade than 52.9% product. Fat requires antioxidant protection. Strict regulatory compliance needed.
regulatory_note: Subject to strict regulations - check local laws on processed animal proteins
notes: Higher protein, lower fat grade of poultry meal. Premium protein source for pigs and aquaculture. BANNED for poultry. Cost-effective fish meal alternative. Excellent amino acid profile. High digestibility. Must be stabilized. Regulatory compliance essential.

name: Processed animal protein, poultry, >70% protein
warning: SPECIES RESTRICTION: CANNOT be fed to poultry (same species). PREMIUM GRADE - highest protein. OK for pigs, ruminants, rabbits, fish. Very expensive - use based on economics. Fat requires stabilization.
regulatory_note: Subject to strict regulations - check local laws on processed animal proteins
notes: Premium poultry protein concentrate. Very high protein with excellent amino acid profile. Near fish meal quality. BANNED for poultry. Excellent for aquaculture (salmonids). High digestibility. Cost is limiting factor. Best used in specialty feeds for high-performance animals.

name: Concentrate, Hendrix Layer 5%
warning: CONCENTRATE - NOT FOR DIRECT FEEDING. Overdosing can cause death. Use ONLY as directed at 5% inclusion (50 kg/ton). Contains extremely high levels of vitamins, minerals, and amino acids.
regulatory_note: REGULATED FEED ADDITIVE. Meets layer production standards. Must be mixed thoroughly. Keep out of reach of children. Contains selenium - toxic in excess.
notes: Layer concentrate premix. Use at exactly 50 kg per ton of complete feed (5%). Provides complete vitamin (A, D3, E, K, B-vitamins), mineral (Ca, P, trace minerals), amino acid (lysine, methionine, threonine, tryptophan) package. DO NOT FEED DIRECTLY. Contains choline (100,000 mg/kg). One bag per 20 tons of feed.

name: Concentrate, GreenMix Layer WAN 2.5%
warning: CONCENTRATE - NOT FOR DIRECT FEEDING. Overdosing lethal. Use ONLY at 2.5% inclusion (25 kg/ton). Contains extremely high nutrient concentrations. Vitamin A (4.8M IU/kg), D3 (1.4M IU/kg), E (20,000 IU/kg).
regulatory_note: REGULATED PREMIX. West Africa specialty formulation. Use exact dosage. Contains Chelated minerals for better absorption. Double-strength vitamin levels vs 5% concentrate.
notes: Layer concentrate for West African market. Use at exactly 25 kg/ton (2.5%). Double-strength vitamins and chelated trace minerals for tropical conditions. Higher vitamin E for heat stress. Complete nutrition package for layers. DO NOT EXCEED 25 kg/ton. Contains choline (200,000 mg/kg). One bag per 40 tons of feed.

name: Concentrate, Terratiga Layer 5%
warning: CONCENTRATE - NOT FOR DIRECT FEEDING. Use ONLY at 5% inclusion (50 kg/ton). Higher fat content (7.68%) than Hendrix. Lower protein but higher methionine. Overdosing can cause severe toxicity.
regulatory_note: REGULATED PREMIX. Complete layer nutrition package. Contains higher fat for energy. Exact dosage required. Contains selenium - toxic in excess.
notes: Alternative layer concentrate formulation. Use at exactly 50 kg/ton (5%). Contains higher fat (7.68%) and methionine (29 g/kg) than Hendrix. Good for high-production layers. Lower protein but higher energy formulation. Complete vitamin (A, D3, E, K, B-vitamins) and mineral package. DO NOT EXCEED 50 kg/ton. Contains choline (100,000 mg/kg).

name: Fodder beet, raw
notes: High moisture, mainly for ruminants

name: Groundnut (peanut) shell
notes: Very high fiber, mainly used as bulking agent

name: Jatropha meal, detoxified, dehulled
notes: Must be properly detoxified, limit to 10% of diet

name: Maize, extruded
notes: Better digestibility than raw maize

name: Methionine Hydroxy Analog (MHA-FA, 88%)
notes: Liquid form, 88% activity relative to DL-methionine

name: Vitamin-Mineral Premix (Layer)
notes: Use 2.5-5 kg per ton of complete feed

name: L-Lysine HCl (98.5%)
warning: Over-supplementation can cause amino acid imbalances and increase nitrogen excretion. Safe handling: avoid inhalation of dust. Not corrosive in HCl form. Store in cool, dry conditions to prevent caking. Maximum 0.8% in most animal diets based on nutritional requirements.
regulatory_note: FDA approved (21 CFR 573.320). EU approved under Regulation (EU) No 2020/997. Must meet purity specification: minimum 98.5% L-Lysine HCl (equivalent to 78% L-Lysine base). Must be produced via fermentation with approved strains (C. glutamicum). GRAS status affirmed. Asian jurisdictions: must comply with local feed additive registration requirements.
notes: First limiting amino acid in corn-soybean diets for swine and poultry. Bioavailability: 100%. Provides 78% L-Lysine base content. Wide global usage in feed formulation. Cost-effective compared to protein-bound lysine. Reduces crude protein requirements and nitrogen emissions. Typical inclusion: 0.1-1.5% depending on species and diet formulation.

name: DL-Methionine (99%)
warning: Sulfur amino acid - can increase sulfur content in diet. Over-supplementation may lead to metabolic acidosis. D-form converted to L-form in vivo with ~90% efficiency in poultry. Dust can be irritating - use respiratory protection. Maximum dietary inclusion typically 0.5% for most species based on requirements.
regulatory_note: FDA approved (21 CFR 573.320). EU approved as feed additive. CAS No. 59-51-8. Must meet feed-grade purity: minimum 99% assay. GRAS status affirmed. Produced via chemical synthesis or fermentation. Global standard for methionine supplementation. Regulatory compliance: must meet heavy metal limits (<20 ppm Pb, <3 ppm As).
notes: Essential sulfur-containing amino acid. First or second limiting in poultry diets. 100% bioavailability by definition. Racemic mixture (50% D-, 50% L-form). D-form converted to L-form in liver. Improves feather development in poultry, lean gain in swine, milk protein in dairy. Reduces nitrogen emissions. Typical inclusion: 0.1-0.5% depending on species. Stable in feed processing. Shelf life up to 24 months in sealed packaging.

name: L-Threonine (98.5%)
warning: Critical for mucin production and gut integrity. Over-supplementation (>1% in diet) can lead to excessive mucin production and reduced nutrient absorption. Important for immune function - deficiency increases disease susceptibility. Safe handling: avoid dust inhalation. Maximum dietary inclusion based on ideal protein ratios (typically 65-70% of lysine level).
regulatory_note: FDA approved (21 CFR 573.320). EU approved as feed additive E 1013. Must meet minimum purity: 98.5% L-Threonine. GRAS status affirmed. Produced via fermentation with Corynebacterium glutamicum. Regulatory compliance: must meet microbiological standards (Salmonella negative, E. coli <10 CFU/g).
notes: Third limiting amino acid in corn-soy diets for poultry and swine. Critical for gut health, immunity, and feather development. 100% bioavailability. Supports mucin synthesis in intestinal tract. Reduces nitrogen emissions when used in low-protein diets. Typical inclusion: 0.05-0.8% depending on species and diet formulation. Stable in feed processing. Shelf life up to 24 months.

name: L-Tryptophan (98.5%)
warning: Precursor for serotonin and melatonin - affects behavior and feed intake. Over-supplementation >0.25% can cause lethargy and reduced activity. Critical during stress periods. Light sensitive - store in opaque packaging. Most expensive essential amino acid. Excessive levels can cause serotonin syndrome-like symptoms.
regulatory_note: FDA approved (21 CFR 573.320). EU approved as feed additive. Must meet minimum purity: 98.5% L-Tryptophan. GRAS status affirmed. Produced via fermentation. Regulatory compliance: must meet microbiological standards (Salmonella negative). Light-sensitive product requires appropriate packaging.
notes: Fourth limiting amino acid in swine, often limiting in poultry under stress. Critical for serotonin synthesis (behavior, feed intake). Important during heat stress and disease challenges. 100% bioavailability. Typical inclusion: 0.05-0.22% depending on species and stress level. Most expensive of major amino acids. Store away from light to prevent degradation.

name: L-Valine (98.5%)
warning: Branched-chain amino acid (BCAA). Competes with leucine and isoleucine for transport - maintain proper BCAA ratios (Leu:Ile:Val typically 2:1:1.2). Over-supplementation can cause BCAA imbalance leading to reduced feed intake. Important for muscle metabolism. Excessive levels may cause insulin resistance. Safe handling: avoid dust inhalation.
regulatory_note: FDA approved (21 CFR 573.320). EU approved as feed additive. Must meet minimum purity: 98.5% L-Valine. GRAS status affirmed. Produced via fermentation. Regulatory compliance: must meet microbiological standards (Salmonella negative).
notes: Fifth limiting amino acid in corn-soy diets for swine. Critical for muscle development and energy metabolism. Part of BCAA complex. 100% bioavailability. Typical inclusion: 0.05-0.9% depending on species and diet formulation. Important for tissue repair. Used in low-protein diets to maintain performance. More expensive than major amino acids but increasingly used in precision nutrition.

name: L-Isoleucine (98.5%)
warning: Branched-chain amino acid (BCAA). Competes with leucine and valine for transport - maintain proper BCAA ratios. Deficiency causes muscle wasting and poor growth. Over-supplementation can cause BCAA imbalance. Safe handling: avoid dust inhalation. Light sensitive - store in opaque containers.
regulatory_note: FDA approved (21 CFR 573.320). EU approved as feed additive. Must meet minimum purity: 98.5% L-Isoleucine. GRAS status affirmed. Produced via fermentation. Regulatory compliance: must meet microbiological standards (Salmonella negative). Light-sensitive product requirements.
notes: Branched-chain amino acid (BCAA). Sixth limiting in some corn-soy diets. Critical for hemoglobin synthesis and energy metabolism. 100% bioavailability. Part of BCAA complex. Typical inclusion: 0.05-0.6% depending on species. Important for immune function. Used in precision nutrition programs. More expensive than major amino acids.

name: L-Arginine (98.5%)
warning: Conditionally essential amino acid. High doses can cause diarrhea and digestive upset. Important for nitric oxide production (vasodilation). Competitively antagonistic with lysine - maintain proper Arg:Lys ratio (typically 1:1 to 1.1:1). Over-supplementation may reduce lysine absorption. Safe handling: avoid dust inhalation.
regulatory_note: FDA approved (21 CFR 573.320). EU approved as feed additive. Must meet minimum purity: 98.5% L-Arginine. GRAS status affirmed. Produced via fermentation. Regulatory compliance: must meet microbiological standards (Salmonella negative). Special requirements for nitric oxide donating compounds.
notes: Essential for poultry (synthesized insufficiently). Critical for growth, feather development, and immunity in poultry. Important for feline nutrition (herpesvirus management). 100% bioavailability. Typical inclusion: 0.1-1.2% depending on species. Particularly important for young animals and breeding stock. More expensive than major amino acids but critical for poultry performance.

name: L-Cysteine (98.5%)
warning: Sulfur-containing amino acid. Can partially replace methionine but not vice versa. Unstable under heat - can be lost during pelleting if not protected. Strong sulfur odor may affect palatability at high levels. Over-supplementation can increase sulfur content and metabolic load. Safe handling: avoid dust inhalation.
regulatory_note: FDA approved (21 CFR 573.320). EU approved as feed additive. Must meet minimum purity: 98.5% L-Cysteine. GRAS status affirmed. Produced via fermentation or protein hydrolysis. Regulatory compliance: must meet microbiological standards (Salmonella negative).
notes: Conditionally essential - can be synthesized from methionine. Important for feather development (keratin synthesis in poultry). Antioxidant properties (glutathione precursor). Typically included as 30-40% of total sulfur amino acids. 100% bioavailability. Heat-labile - may lose 10-15% during pelleting >80Â°C. Typical inclusion: 0.05-0.4% depending on species. More cost-effective than methionine for sulfur supply but less stable.

name: L-Threonine 50% (liquid)
warning: LIQUID FORM - handle with appropriate pumping equipment. 50% concentration requires double inclusion rate vs powder form. Can promote microbial growth in storage tanks if not properly sanitized. pH typically 5-7. Crystallization risk if stored below 5Â°C. Requires agitated storage tanks to prevent settling. Maximum 2% in most species based on liquid form equivalency.
regulatory_note: FDA approved for liquid addition systems. EU approved as feed additive. Must meet specification: 50% L-Threonine concentration. Storage tank requirements: food-grade materials, sanitization protocol required. Must meet microbiological standards (total plate count <1000 CFU/ml). Not for direct water medication without approval.
notes: Liquid form for automated addition systems. Provides flexibility in feed manufacturing. 100% bioavailability. Requires specialized storage and handling infrastructure. Cost-effective for large feed mills. Reduces dust compared to powder. Typical liquid inclusion: 0.1-1.6% diet (adjust for 50% concentration). Stable for 12 months in proper storage. Requires corrosion-resistant equipment (stainless steel).

name: L-Lysine 70% Sulphate
warning: Contains sulphate carrier (30% of product). Sulfur content may increase diet sulfate levels. Less concentrated than HCl form (55% vs 78% lysine base). Requires higher inclusion rates. Can affect diet electrolyte balance. Sulphate may interact with other minerals. Safe handling: dust can be irritating.
regulatory_note: FDA approved (21 CFR 573.320). EU approved as feed additive. Must meet specification: minimum 55% L-Lysine base (equivalent to 70% L-Lysine sulphate). FAMI-QS certification required. Sulphate content must be declared. Must meet heavy metal limits. GRAS status affirmed.
notes: Liquid base form - alkaline (pH 10.7-11.0). More concentrated than HCl form (65% vs 78% base). Requires specialized handling systems. Cost-effective for large operations. Corrosive properties require specialized storage tanks (stainless steel 316L or fiberglass). 100% bioavailability. Typical liquid inclusion: 0.1-2.4% diet (adjust for 65% concentration and high pH). Not for direct water medication without pH adjustment. Stable for 12 months in proper storage. Higher risk than HCl form but lower cost per unit lysine.; Alternative to L-Lysine HCl. Contains sulphate carrier (30%). Lower lysine concentration requires higher inclusion rates. 100% bioavailability. Cost-competitive alternative to HCl form. Typical inclusion: adjust for 55% lysine base content. Sulfur content beneficial for wool/hair growth in some species. Dusty - requires proper handling. Stable in feed processing. Shelf life up to 24 months.

name: Corn DDGS (hi-pro)
warning: Lysine is limiting amino acid - requires supplementation. Variable nutrient content based on corn source and processing. Risk of mycotoxin contamination (aflatoxin, DON, fumonisin) - test every batch. High fat content can oxidize if not stabilized with antioxidants. High fiber from distillers grains can affect pellet quality.
regulatory_note: FDA approved feed ingredient. Must meet AAFCO specifications for crude protein (min 28%), fat (min 5%), and fiber (max 12%). Mycotoxin limits: <20 ppb aflatoxin, <5 ppm DON for swine. Phosphorus availability >85% must be declared. Grain origin must be declared per FDA requirements.
notes: Most abundant co-product from US ethanol industry. High-protein (>30% CP) and low-fat (<8% fat) varieties available. Excellent phosphorus source (>85% digestible). Can replace soybean meal + corn combination in most diets. Use crystalline lysine to balance amino acids. Test for sulfur content (can be high from sulfuric acid use).

name: Bakery meal
warning: Extremely variable composition based on source bakery products. Can contain high salt (>1.5% NaCl), sugar, and preservatives. Risk of rancidity from high fat. May contain chocolate or other prohibited ingredients for ruminants. Quality control critical. Mycotoxin risk if old/stale products used.
regulatory_note: FDA approved feed ingredient. Must be from approved bakery sources. Maximum salt content must be declared if >0.5%. Prohibited ingredients (chocolate, meat products) cannot be included per BSE regulations. Must meet AAFCO specifications for processed grain products. BSE compliance documentation required.
notes: Composition varies: bread, cookies, crackers, etc. Salt content can be high - check each batch. Excellent energy source similar to corn. Fat can be 8-15% depending on sources. Generally very palatable. Screen for foreign objects and packaging materials.

name: Citrus pulp (dried)
warning: Extremely high calcium (22.5 g/kg) creates severe Ca:P imbalance (>18:1) causing urinary calculi in male ruminants. Contains limonene and essential oils that can cause feed refusal if >15% inclusion. High pectin content can cause digestive upset. Low energy density. Tannins (2.8%) bind proteins.
regulatory_note: FDA approved byproduct feed. Maximum inclusion 20% in ruminant diets to prevent urinary calculi. Calcium level must be declared (>20 g/kg). Must be dried to <10% moisture to prevent mold. Not permitted in poultry starter feeds (<21 days). Mycotoxin risk if moldy fruit processed.
notes: Byproduct of orange/lemon juice processing. Unpalatable at high inclusion - introduce gradually. Pectin is highly fermentable in rumen producing propionate. Good source of digestible fiber (60% NDF digestibility). Counteract high calcium with phosphorus and salt supplementation.

name: Cottonseed meal (de-gossypol)
warning: Contains gossypol pigment - must be from de-gossypol solvent extraction or glandless cotton varieties. Free gossypol must be <100 ppm for pigs, <400 ppm for poultry. Can cause cardiac and testicular damage at high levels. Glandless varieties are safer but less available. High phytic acid reduces mineral availability.
regulatory_note: FDA approved but restricted. Must specify free gossypol content. Maximum free gossypol: 100 ppm for swine, 400 ppm for poultry. Not permitted in calf replacers. Must be from glandless cotton or de-gossypol process. Phytase supplementation recommended. BSE-free certification required.
notes: Glandless cotton varieties eliminate gossypol issue. Solvent extraction reduces free gossypol to <0.02%. Excellent protein quality, low fiber. Higher inclusion possible with glandless types. Monitor for aflatoxin contamination. Good phosphorus source (>70% digestible) when phytase added.

name: Peanut skins (tannin-managed)
warning: Very high tannin content (4.8%) severely limits use in monogastrics - can cause protein binding, reduced growth, and feed refusal. Tannin-managed varieties have <2% tannins but are rare. Risk of aflatoxin contamination if peanuts were moldy. High fiber reduces digestibility.
regulatory_note: FDA approved but restricted. Tannin content must be declared if >2%. Not permitted in starter feeds without detoxification. Maximum inclusion: 5% for swine and poultry. Must meet aflatoxin limits for peanuts (<20 ppb). Organic status depends on peanut sourcing.
notes: Byproduct of peanut blanching. Very cheap but limited by tannins. Tannin-binding agents (PEG) can improve utilization but not cost-effective. Best used in ruminant diets where tannins can be beneficial (bloat prevention). High inclusion causes dark, sticky feces in poultry.

name: Feather meal (hydrolyzed)
warning: Very high protein (85%) but poor digestibility if not properly hydrolyzed. Heat processing can damage amino acids if too severe. Lysine and methionine limiting. High cystine can be problematic if unbalanced. Unpalatable at high inclusion - use in combination with other proteins. Risk of disease transmission if not properly processed.
regulatory_note: FDA approved but must be properly hydrolyzed (rendered) to destroy pathogens per 21 CFR 589.2000. Must meet Salmonella-free requirements. Processed under 9 CFR 500 regulations. Not permitted in ruminant feeds in some states due to BSE concerns. Specify ruminant-safe sourcing.
notes: Rendered poultry feathers - very sustainable protein source. Proper hydrolysis breaks keratin bonds improving digestibility (>75%). Excellent cystine source. Low palatability requires gradual introduction. Best used at 3-5% in most feeds. Cost-effective compared to fish meal. Must be from BSE-free sources.

name: Meat & bone meal (feed-grade, ruminant-free)
warning: BANNED FOR RUMINANT FEEDING in USA & Canada due to BSE risk (21 CFR 589.2000). Must be from ruminant-free facilities and certified. Very high calcium and phosphorus can imbalance ratios. Fat can oxidize causing rancidity. Quality variable based on raw materials. Risk of pathogens if not properly rendered.
regulatory_note: CANNOT BE FED TO RUMINANTS per FDA BSE prevention regulations. Must be from non-ruminant species (porcine, poultry) only. Must meet AAFCO processing standards (minimum 133°C for 20 min). Salmonella-free certification required. Ash content 25-35% typical. Calcium declaration mandatory.
notes: Feed-grade only - not for pet foods. Excellent calcium and phosphorus source for layers. Should not exceed 15% due to high mineral content. Use in swine finishing diets for bone/structural support. Must have clear ruminant-free supply chain documentation. Quality controlled by ARA (Animal Protein Producers Industry).

name: Poultry by-product meal (feed-grade)
warning: High calcium (75 g/kg) and phosphorus (42 g/kg) can imbalance ratios if inclusion >15%. Fat can oxidize causing rancidity - requires antioxidants. Quality variable based on processing and raw materials. Risk of pathogens if not properly rendered. Unpalatable at high inclusion - use in combination.
regulatory_note: FDA approved per AAFCO standards. Must be properly rendered (minimum 133°C for 20 min) to kill pathogens per 9 CFR 500. Salmonella-free certification required. Ash content 15-25% typical. Must declare calcium and phosphorus content. BSE-free guarantee required for export.
notes: High-quality animal protein from slaughterhouse byproducts (heads, feet, organs). Should not exceed 15% due to high mineral content. Excellent amino acid profile for poultry and fish feeds. Better digestibility than meat & bone meal. More consistent quality than meat & bone meal. Use in grower/finisher swine diets for lean gain.

name: Alfalfa pellets (sun-cured)
warning: Very high calcium (18.5 g/kg) can imbalance Ca:P ratio to >6:1. Contains saponins that can cause bloat in ruminants if >30% of diet. High fiber limits digestibility in monogastrics. Can contain phytoestrogens affecting reproduction. Vitamin D content variable based on sun-curing. Risk of pesticide/herbicide residues.
regulatory_note: FDA approved forage product. Maximum inclusion in swine feeds: 10% to avoid mineral imbalances. Forage source must be declared (sun-cured vs dehy). Pesticide/herbicide testing may be required for organic certification. Calcium content must be declared. Not for fish diets.
notes: Available as sun-cured (lower quality, cheaper) or dehy (dehydrated, higher quality, more expensive). Good source of xanthophylls for yolk color. High protein for a forage but poor amino acid digestibility. Excellent for ruminant roughage. Contains natural antioxidants (vitamin E, carotene).

name: Alfalfa pellets (dehydrated)
warning: High calcium (16.5 g/kg) can imbalance Ca:P ratio. Contains saponins that can cause bloat in ruminants if >35% of diet. Dehydrated form has better nutrient retention than sun-cured. Phytoestrogens may affect reproduction in breeding animals. High quality but more expensive than sun-cured.
regulatory_note: FDA approved. Higher quality than sun-cured due to lower fiber and better protein. Maximum inclusion in swine: 12% to avoid mineral imbalances. Must declare protein quality (dehy vs sun-cured). Pesticide testing for organic. Calcium declaration mandatory. Not for fish diets.
notes: Dehydrated within hours of harvest for maximum nutrient retention. Higher protein (18-22%) and lower fiber than sun-cured. Better carotene and xanthophyll content. More consistent quality. Premium forage ingredient. Excellent for dairy cows - high bypass protein fraction.

name: Shea nut cake
warning: Extremely high tannin content (8.2%) severely limits use in monogastrics. Tannins bind proteins and reduce digestibility. Contains saponins and other bitter compounds. Can reduce palatability and feed intake. Must be processed (fermentation/extraction) to reduce tannins.
regulatory_note: Limited approval as feed ingredient. High tannin varieties restricted to ruminants only. Detoxification required for monogastric use. Maximum tannin content: 1% for poultry, 2% for pigs if detoxified. Not permitted in EU organic feed.
notes: Byproduct of shea butter extraction. Very limited nutritional value due to tannins. Ruminants can tolerate higher levels due to tannin-protein complex formation in rumen. Consider chemical analysis before each batch. Very variable nutrient content.

name: Baobab seed meal
warning: High tannin content (2.8%) reduces protein digestibility. Contains phytic acid that reduces mineral bioavailability. Must be processed (fermented/extruded) to improve nutrient availability. Variable nutrient content based on tree age and processing.
regulatory_note: Traditional feed ingredient in Africa. Novel in EU and USA. Detoxification may be required for high inclusion rates. Maximum tannin content: 1.5% for monogastrics if processed. Heavy metal testing recommended.
notes: Exceptional calcium content from seed coat. Good energy source (44.6% NFE). Processing (dehulling, cooking) reduces tannins and phytic acid. Potential prebiotic effects from soluble fiber. Sustainable use of underutilized African tree crop.

name: Jatropha kernel cake (detox, research-only)
warning: RESEARCH ONLY - NOT FOR COMMERCIAL FEED. Contains phorbol esters that are toxic to monogastrics and potentially toxic to ruminants. Can cause severe diarrhea, liver/kidney damage, and mortality. Detoxification not yet commercially viable. Extreme caution required.
regulatory_note: NOT APPROVED for commercial feed. Research use only with full safety protocols. Ph.Eur. includes jatropha oil as toxic substance. Multiple jurisdictions prohibit use in animal feed. Requires regulatory exemption for research.
notes: NOT FOR COMMERCIAL FORMULATION. High protein content is attractive but toxins make it unsafe. Current research on biological/chemical detoxification. Multiple research institutions investigating safety. DO NOT USE IN PRODUCTION FEEDS.

name: Bambara groundnut meal
warning: Contains trypsin inhibitors, tannins, and phytic acid. Requires heat treatment (cooking/roasting) to improve protein digestibility. Hard-to-cook phenomenon requires extended cooking time. Dark seed coats have higher tannin content.
regulatory_note: Traditional African food/feed ingredient. Approved in most jurisdictions. Processing required to reduce anti-nutritional factors. Low-tannin varieties (white/cream seeds) preferred for monogastrics. Must meet grain legume quality standards.
notes: Underutilized African legume with good nutritional profile. High in lysine compared to other legumes. Soaking and cooking reduces ANFs by 60-70%. Drought tolerant crop - good for climate resilience. Variable tannin content based on seed coat color.

name: Cowpea haulms
warning: High fiber content limits digestibility in monogastrics. Risk of aflatoxin contamination if not properly dried. Should be harvested at pod maturity for optimal quality. Contains moderate tannins that reduce protein digestibility.
regulatory_note: Approved forage ingredient in most jurisdictions. Must meet forage quality standards. Moisture content must be <13% for storage. Mycotoxin testing required in humid regions. Considered safe for all livestock classes when properly processed.
notes: Dual-purpose legume - grain for human/feed, haulms for fodder. Better protein quality than cereal straws. Sun-drying within 48 hours critical for quality. Can be used as silage when mixed with grasses. Not suitable for high-producing animals as sole forage.

name: Sorghum malt sprout
warning: Contains moderate trypsin inhibitors that reduce protein digestibility. Tannins from sorghum can reduce palatability. Variable nutrient content based on malting process and sorghum variety. Risk of mycotoxin contamination if sorghum was moldy.
regulatory_note: Approved brewing byproduct. Must meet specifications for protein, fiber, and ash. Mycotoxin testing recommended if sourced from suspect grain. Trypsin inhibitor activity should be <10 TUI/mg protein.
notes: Good protein source for the price. Contains residual amylases from malting process. Fiber is partially fermentable. Better feeding value than raw sorghum due to enzyme activation. Can replace soybean meal up to 25% in grower pig diets with amino acid supplementation.

name: Millet bran
warning: High fiber content (22.5%) can limit digestibility in young monogastrics. Contains phytic acid that reduces mineral bioavailability. Tannins present in some varieties reduce protein digestibility. Risk of mycotoxin contamination if stored damp.
regulatory_note: Approved cereal byproduct. Must meet bran quality standards. Mycotoxin testing required for products from suspect regions. Phytase supplementation recommended for monogastric diets. Maximum fiber: 25% for poultry.
notes: Better protein quality than wheat bran. Pearl millet bran preferred over finger millet due to lower tannins. Good source of B-vitamins and minerals. Fermentable fiber beneficial for gut health. Can replace 20-30% of cereal grains in finishing diets.

name: Groundnut shells (fiber)
warning: Extremely high fiber (65%) makes it indigestible for monogastrics. Very low nutritional value. Can cause impaction if fed at high levels. Dusty - respiratory irritant. Must be ground for ruminants to improve utilization.
regulatory_note: Approved as roughage source only. Not permitted as primary feed ingredient for monogastrics. Must be free from aflatoxin contamination. Maximum inclusion in complete feeds: 5% for poultry, 3% for pigs.
notes: Very cheap fiber source for ruminants in peanut-growing regions. Can be used as bedding and then fed. Better utilized when ammoniated or treated with alkali. Not suitable for high-producing animals. Consider transportation cost vs. nutritional value.

name: Sunflower cake (high fiber)
warning: High fiber content (28%) limits digestibility, especially in young monogastrics. Lysine is limiting amino acid. Contains chlorogenic acid that can oxidize and reduce palatability. High fiber can cause pellet quality issues. Phytic acid reduces mineral availability.
regulatory_note: Approved oilseed meal. Must meet specifications for crude fiber (max 30%), fat (min 5%), and protein (min 26%). Phytase supplementation recommended for monogastric diets. Not permitted for fish in EU due to fiber content.
notes: Available as high-fiber (dehulled) or low-fiber varieties. High-fiber version is cheaper but less digestible. Good methionine content for poultry. Heat treatment (toasted) improves digestibility and reduces oxidation. Popular in sunflower-growing regions of Southern Africa.

name: Brewer's spent grain (dried)
warning: High moisture content in fresh form (75-80%) causes rapid spoilage. Dried form is stable but bulky. Contains residual bitter compounds from hops that can reduce palatability. High fiber can cause digestive upset if inclusion too high. Risk of mycotoxin contamination if storage inadequate.
regulatory_note: Approved brewing byproduct. Must be stabilized to prevent spoilage. Mycotoxin testing recommended. Fresh form requires on-farm feeding within 3-5 days. Dried form has longer shelf life. Not permitted in organic feed if hops were non-organic.
notes: Wet form (75-80% moisture) is very cheap but logistics challenging. Dried form increases cost but improves storability. Good rumen bypass protein for dairy cattle. Can partially replace forage in ruminant diets due to fiber digestibility (55-60% NDFd).

name: Rapeseed meal (low-GSL)
warning: Contains glucosinolates (12 μmol/g limit for low-GSL varieties). Must be from double-zero (00) varieties. Can cause thyroid enlargement and reduced growth if GSL >15 μmol/g. High fiber in seed coat reduces digestibility. Erucic acid content must be <2% in oil.
regulatory_note: EU Register of Feed Materials approved. Must be from low-glucosinolate varieties (<18 μmol/g total GSL). Maximum erucic acid in oilseed meals: 2%. Not permitted in organic feed if solvent-extracted. Phytase supplementation recommended.
notes: Double-zero varieties (low GSL <12 Î¼mol/g, low erucic acid) are standard in EU. Excellent amino acid profile for plant protein. Heat treatment (toasting) improves digestibility and reduces GSL. Cost-effective alternative to soybean meal.; Double-zero varieties (low GSL <12 μmol/g, low erucic acid) are standard in EU.
