Excellent amino acid profile for plant protein. Heat treatment (toasting) improves digestibility and reduces GSL. Cost-effective alternative to soybean meal.

name: Sunflower expeller (hi-pro)
warning: Lysine is limiting amino acid. High fiber content reduces digestibility in young animals. Chlorogenic acid can oxidize, causing feed refusal. Phytic acid reduces mineral bioavailability. Oil content prone to rancidity if not stabilized.
regulatory_note: EU approved feed material. Must meet specifications for crude fiber (max 18%) and fat (min 12% for hi-fat, 5-8% for deoiled). Phytase recommended for monogastric diets. Not permitted in organic if solvent-extracted.
notes: Available as high-protein (38-40% CP, 15% CF) or low-protein (32-34% CP, 22% CF). Hi-pro version is dehulled with higher digestibility. Good selenium source for European diets. Toasting improves protein quality and reduces oxidation.

name: Beet pulp (dried)
warning: Very high calcium (11.5 g/kg) can imbalance Ca:P ratio to >10:1, causing urinary calculi in male ruminants and zinc deficiency. Must be soaked before feeding to prevent choke. Can cause diarrhea if introduced too rapidly. Low phosphorus content requires supplementation.
regulatory_note: EU approved feed material (Register 002327). Maximum inclusion 25% in ruminant diets to maintain mineral balance. Must declare calcium content on label. Recommended Ca:P ratio must not exceed 3:1 in complete diet. Not for fish diets due to high calcium.
notes: Excellent pectin source (25% of fiber) - highly fermentable in rumen. Good energy from volatile fatty acids. Soak in water 1:2 ratio for 30 minutes before feeding. Can replace 25% of hay in dairy rations. Very palatable and reduces sorting in TMR.

name: Distillers wheat grains
warning: Lysine is limiting amino acid. High phosphorus availability (>80%) requires calcium supplementation. Sulfur content can be high - monitor for polioencephalomalacia in ruminants if sulfur >0.4% of diet. Variable nutrient content based on wheat quality and distillation process.
regulatory_note: EU approved co-product (Register 002505). Must meet specifications for protein, fiber, and ash. High phosphorus availability declared on label. Maximum sulfur content: 0.5% in complete feed. Mycotoxin testing required if wheat was of suspect quality.
notes: Excellent alternative to corn DDGS in wheat-growing regions. Lower fat than corn DDGS reduces rancidity risk. High digestible fiber (65% NDFd) excellent for dairy cows. Can replace soybean meal + cereal grain combination. Protein quality improves with amino acid supplementation.

name: Pea hulls
warning: Very high fiber (50% minimum) and extremely low energy. Very bulky - can reduce feed intake if inclusion too high. Dusty - respiratory irritant during handling. Very low digestibility for monogastrics. Risk of pesticide residues if not organic.
regulatory_note: EU approved as fiber source (Register 013171). Maximum 10% in ruminant complete feeds, 5% in pig feeds, 3% in poultry feeds. Must be free from mycotoxin contamination. Low energy content must be declared on label. Not for fish feeds.
notes: Byproduct of pea protein isolation. Pure insoluble fiber (cellulose). Very low fermentability (slow fermentation rate) good for gut motility without excessive gas production. Used in diabetic pet foods for low glycemic impact. Good for hairball control in rabbits.

name: Faba bean meal (tannin-managed)
warning: Low methionine content requires supplementation. Contains vicine/convicine in colored-flower varieties that can cause favism (hemolysis) in sensitive animals. Tannin-managed varieties (white-flowering) reduce this risk. Trypsin inhibitors reduce protein digestibility. Must be heat-treated.
regulatory_note: EU approved (Register 000608). Must be from low-tannin varieties (white/cream flowers). Vicine/convicine content must be <0.1% in monogastric feeds. Heat processing required to inactivate trypsin inhibitors. Organic approved if sourced from organic farms.
notes: Tannin-managed (zero-tannin) varieties have white flowers. Traditional varieties with colored flowers have high tannins and vicine/convicine. Excellent protein quality for European-grown legume. Good amino acid profile except methionine. Fermentation improves digestibility.

name: Lupin meal (sweet varieties)
warning: Low methionine and cystine content requires supplementation. Contains alkaloids (sparteine, lupanine) in bitter varieties - must use sweet/low-alkaloid varieties only. High fiber (16%) limits use in young poultry. Trypsin inhibitors reduce protein digestibility. Must be heat-treated.
regulatory_note: EU approved (Register 000688). Must be from sweet/low-alkaloid varieties (<0.02% total alkaloids). Alkaloid content must be declared. Heat processing required to inactivate trypsin inhibitors. Organic approved. Maximum fiber: 18% for poultry feeds.
notes: Sweet lupins (L. albus, L. angustifolius) have <0.02% alkaloids. White lupin has highest protein (36-38%). Australian sweet lupins most common. Good amino acid profile except sulfur amino acids. Fermentation or enzyme treatment improves digestibility. Sustainable European protein source.

name: Brewer's spent grain
warning: Moisture content in fresh form 78% - must be used within 3-5 days or dried. Contains residual hop compounds that can reduce palatability. High fiber can cause digestive upset if introduced too rapidly. Lysine limiting. Risk of spoilage and mycotoxin growth in warm weather.
regulatory_note: EU approved co-product (Register 013171). Fresh form requires HACCP for short shelf-life management. Dried form must have moisture <12%. Mycotoxin testing recommended. Not for fish diets due to high fiber and hop residues. Must meet microbiological standards.
notes: Major co-product from European brewing industry. Very cost-effective protein source. Wet form requires local sourcing. Dried form is stable and transportable. Good source of B-vitamins from yeast. Fiber digestibility 55-60% in rumen. Can replace 30% of concentrate in dairy rations.

name: Copra expeller (high fat)
warning: High in medium-chain saturated fatty acids (lauric, myristic). Low in lysine and other essential amino acids. Contains mannan polysaccharides that increase digesta viscosity. Risk of rancidity due to high oil content. High fiber reduces pellet quality.
regulatory_note: Approved feed ingredient. Must specify fat content (high fat = >8% residual oil). Quality parameter: maximum 12% crude fiber. Must meet ash specifications (<7%).
notes: Also available as low-fat variant (<5% oil). High-fat version provides energy but reduces pellet durability. Good rumen bypass protein source for dairy cattle.

name: Rice bran (stabilized)
warning: Unstabilized rice bran can become rancid within days due to lipase activity. High phytic acid reduces mineral bioavailability. Contains trypsin inhibitor. High oil content may cause soft carcass fat in pigs. Risk of aflatoxin contamination.
regulatory_note: Must be stabilized to prevent rancidity (FFA <10%). Meets FDA requirements for rice bran products. Phytase supplementation recommended for monogastric diets. Must meet mycotoxin standards.
notes: Stabilization via heating or extrusion inactivates lipase. De-oiled version also available. Excellent source of B-vitamins and oryzanol. High phosphorus requires calcium supplementation. Most widely used rice byproduct in Southeast Asia.

name: Cassava chip meal (detoxified)
warning: Must be properly detoxified to reduce cyanogenic glycosides (linamarin) to <10 mg/kg HCN equivalent. Inadequate processing can release lethal cyanide. Test every batch for residual cyanide. Dusty - respiratory risk during handling. Low protein quality.
regulatory_note: Must comply with CODEX STAN 238 (sweet cassava <50 mg/kg cyanide). Detoxification process must be validated. HACCP protocol required for cyanide control. Not permitted for piglets or starter poultry without certification.
notes: Primary energy source replacement for corn. Sun-drying followed by water soaking for 24h reduces cyanide by 80%. Fermentation further reduces cyanide. High starch digestibility (>90%). Very economical in Southeast Asia.

name: Sago palm meal
warning: Very bulky with low bulk density. Low protein and micronutrient content. High fiber reduces digestibility in monogastrics. Quality variable based on processing method. May contain residual bark/contaminants if poorly processed.
regulatory_note: Generally recognized as safe (GRAS) for livestock feed. Quality standards vary by country. Must be free from palm bark and other contaminants. Maximum ash content: 4%.
notes: Produced from sago palm starch extraction waste. Lower energy than cassava due to higher fiber. Best for ruminants where fiber is beneficial. Limited micronutrient content requires vitamin/mineral premix supplementation.

name: Duckweed fresh/meal
warning: Quality highly variable based on growing conditions and nutrient media. Risk of heavy metal contamination if grown in polluted water. Must be grown in controlled conditions or tested for contaminants. Fresh duckweed spoils rapidly - must be dried within 24 hours.
regulatory_note: Not currently approved as commercial feed ingredient in EU or USA. Requires Novel Food/Feed assessment. Heavy metal testing mandatory if sourced from natural water bodies. Maximum inclusion limits apply to dried form only.
notes: Grown on nutrient-rich wastewater in controlled systems. Exceptional protein quality comparable to soybean meal. Very high mineral content may require diet reformulation. Fresh form has 92-94% moisture, dried form 8-10% moisture.

name: Seaweed meal (Ulva spp.)
warning: High iodine content (>1000 ppm) can cause thyroid dysfunction if >5% inclusion. High ash content (28%) may dilute energy content. Risk of heavy metal bioaccumulation (arsenic, cadmium) if harvested from polluted coastal waters. Test for contaminants.
regulatory_note: Novel feed ingredient requiring pre-market approval in most jurisdictions. Must be harvested from clean water sources with heavy metal testing. Iodine content must be declared on label. EU requires novel food safety assessment.
notes: Excellent source of trace minerals and marine polysaccharides. Ulva (sea lettuce) has better digestibility than Sargassum. High prebiotic fiber content supports gut health. Fresh or dried forms available. Dried form has 90% DM.

name: Sweet potato peels
warning: Contains trypsin inhibitors and small amounts of cyanogenic compounds in fresh peels. Must be heat-treated (cooked/sundried) to reduce anti-nutritional factors. High moisture content can lead to rapid spoilage. Risk of pesticide residues if not organic.
regulatory_note: Approved fruit/vegetable processing byproduct. Must meet pesticide residue limits. Heat treatment required to reduce anti-nutritional factors. Maximum aflatoxin: 20 ppb.
notes: Excellent source of digestible carbohydrates (52% starch). Good energy value for monogastrics. Tannins in peel reduce protein digestibility. Drying at >85Â°C for 30 minutes eliminates most anti-nutritional factors. Vitamin A precursor content beneficial for poultry.; Excellent source of digestible carbohydrates (52% starch). Good energy value for monogastrics. Tannins in peel reduce protein digestibility. Drying at >85°C for 30 minutes eliminates most anti-nutritional factors. Vitamin A precursor content beneficial for poultry.

name: Taro leaves (detox)
warning: Contains calcium oxalate crystals (raphides) that cause oral irritation and kidney damage. Detoxification by cooking/boiling required to dissolve oxalates. High calcium content can imbalance Ca:P ratio. Contains protease inhibitors.
regulatory_note: Must be heat-treated to reduce oxalate toxicity. Maximum calcium oxalate: 0.5%. Not permitted in starter feeds without certification. Must meet pesticide residue standards for leafy vegetables.
notes: Boiling for 30 minutes reduces oxalates by 85%. Excellent calcium source (2.5%). High-quality protein for a leafy material. Use as functional protein in tropical regions. Palatability improved after processing.

name: Water spinach (Ipomoea aquatica)
warning: Fresh form has 88% moisture - spoilage risk high. Contains oxalates and saponins. May accumulate heavy metals if grown in contaminated water. Drying required for storage. Low dry matter yield.
regulatory_note: Generally recognized as safe for livestock feed in Asia-Pacific region. Must meet pesticide residue limits if cultivated commercially. Heavy metal testing recommended for aquatic-sourced material.
notes: Excellent protein source for tropical regions. Very fast-growing (harvest every 21 days). High moisture content makes transport costly. Dried meal is concentrated protein source. Rich in carotenoids for yolk color enhancement.

name: Mustard cake (low-glucosinolate)
warning: Contains glucosinolates that can cause thyroid enlargement and liver damage. Maximum free glucosinolate level: 15 μmol/g. Must be sourced from low-GSL varieties only. Not recommended for fish due to thyroid-disrupting effects.
regulatory_note: Must comply with EU Directive 2002/32/EC on undesirable substances. Maximum glucosinolate content regulated in EU feed. Banned for aquafeed in EU.
notes: Indian low-GSL varieties (e.g., Varuna, Kranti) are preferred. Requires quarterly testing for glucosinolate levels.

name: Groundnut haulms
warning: High fiber forage with low digestibility. Risk of aflatoxin contamination if not properly dried. Should be sun-dried to <12% moisture within 48 hours of harvest.
regulatory_note: Must comply with FDA aflatoxin limits for feed (<20 ppb for dairy cattle). Monitor for Aspergillus contamination in humid climates.
notes: Best used as roughage for ruminants. Protein quality is poor with low lysine. Harvest at pod maturity for optimal nutrient content.

name: Red gram (pigeon pea) husk
warning: Very high fiber, low digestibility. Contains condensed tannins that reduce protein digestibility. Must be processed (ground/extruded) to improve utilization. Risk of mycotoxin contamination if stored improperly.
regulatory_note: Considered as roughage ingredient. Not permitted as primary protein source. Must meet quality standards for fiber sources under EU feed legislation.
notes: Used primarily as fiber source in ruminant diets. Very low energy density. Best suited for gestating cows and dry ewes. Not recommended for high-producing animals.

name: Cottonseed hulls (low gossypol)
warning: Free gossypol content must be <100 ppm for safe feeding to adult ruminants. Zero inclusion for pigs and poultry due to gossypol toxicity. Maximum free gossypol: 0.06% (600 ppm). Monitor for aflatoxin contamination.
regulatory_note: Must meet FDA guidelines for cottonseed products. Free gossypol analysis required for each batch. Not permitted for swine, poultry, or fish feeds in most jurisdictions.
notes: Excellent fiber source for ruminants. Very low nutritional value for monogastrics. Use primarily as roughage extender in drought conditions. Free gossypol content typically 0.04-0.08%.

name: Neem seed cake (detox)
warning: Contains azadirachtin (triterpenoids) and other bitter compounds. Detoxification required via water washing or solvent extraction. Residual azadirachtin can reduce palatability and cause digestive upset. Maximum residual azadirachtin: 100 ppm.
regulatory_note: Novel ingredient in many jurisdictions. Requires safety assessment and registration. Detoxification process must be validated. Not permitted in EU organic feed.
notes: Detoxification reduces anti-nutritional factors by 70-80%. Use as protein supplement in ruminant diets. Monitor for residual pesticides used in neem cultivation.

name: Tamarind seed meal (detox)
warning: Contains high levels of condensed tannins (3.2%) that can bind proteins and reduce digestibility. Detoxification required via water extraction or fermentation. Test for residual cyanogenic compounds. Maximum tannin content: 3.5%.
regulatory_note: Novel ingredient in many regions. Requires safety assessment. Detoxification process must be validated and documented. Monitor for Salmonella contamination during processing.
notes: Detoxification reduces tannin content by 60-70%. Good energy source due to high starch content. Use as partial replacement for cereal grains in monogastric diets.

name: Karanja cake (detox)
warning: Contains karanjin, pongamia oil, and other furano-flavonoids that are toxic to monogastrics. Detoxification via water/ethanol extraction required. Residual toxicity can cause liver damage and reduced growth. Test for residual karanjin.
regulatory_note: Restricted ingredient in EU and USA. Requires pre-market approval. Detoxification must be certified. Maximum karanjin residue: 100 ppm. Not permitted in organic feed systems.
notes: Similar to neem cake but with different toxic profile. Detoxification reduces ANFs by 65-75%. Use primarily in ruminant diets. Monitor for residual oil content (>8% reduces palatability).

name: De-oiled rice bran (stabilized)
warning: High phytic acid content reduces mineral bioavailability. Requires phytase supplementation for monogastrics. Stabilization prevents rancidity but does not eliminate phytic acid. Contains high phosphorus relative to calcium.
regulatory_note: Widely approved feed ingredient. Stabilization process must prevent free fatty acid formation (<10% FFA). Meets FDA requirements for rice bran products. Phosphorus content requires calcium supplementation.
notes: Stabilization via extrusion or heating prevents rancidity. Good source of B-vitamins and oryzanol. High phosphorus content beneficial for layers but requires calcium balancing. Strongly recommended for ruminant diets.

name: Sorghum DDGS
warning: Lysine is limiting amino acid. Variable nutrient content based on sorghum variety and processing. Risk of mycotoxin contamination (aflatoxin, fumonisin). Test each batch. High fiber content may affect pellet quality.
regulatory_note: Approved feed ingredient in most jurisdictions. Must meet FDA mycotoxin limits (<20 ppb aflatoxin). Nutrient guarantee required for protein, fat, and fiber. Phosphorus availability is high (>80%).
notes: Excellent phosphorus source (>80% digestible). Lower lysine than corn DDGS but good energy value. Use with crystalline lysine supplementation. More variable than corn DDGS due to sorghum tannin content.
